text: Bottle at home. Pours hazy pale yellow with a large, creamy and tight-bubbled white head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is moderate doughy, biscuit and cracker Pils malt, lightly sweet with light spicy and earthy hops; quite clean. Flavor is clean and lightly sweet doughy, biscuit, cracker Pils malt with light spicy and earthy hops and a peppery bitterness and a dry finish. Medium-light body and moderate carbonation.
From a 50 cl bottle. Pours a clear greenish gold with an off white head. Aroma of bread yeast. Flavors of lemon and bread pudding. Smooth finish. Very tasty for the style.

Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is medium yellow. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain, sourdough bread), lightly to moderately hoppy (flowers, herbs), with notes of sulfur, concrete, kumquat. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation.

Ive had two different batches of this so far...one that was 1 day old (11/30 bottling drank Dec 1), and another that they said was probably about a month old, which is what Im rating here. The fresher one was surprisingly not much hoppier than this one, but this older one seems to have more yeasty character, and is closer to real Kellerbier than perhaps anything Ive had in the US so far. Sourdough and sulfur along with a yeasty tang, and while its not bottle conditioned it does contain light sediment and haze. You could tell me this was made in some small Franconian countryside brewery and Id believe it. And thats perhaps what I like the most about it...its so un-American. There are things about it I could like more, and truth be told I dont *quite* find it truly exciting from a purely organoleptic perspective. But I absolutely love the fact that its so much like something youd find on trip through rural Germany...and that is worth an extra point or two for sure.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2016 From bottle its mostly clear gold with a short head. Noble hop aroma is lemon, herbs, mint; malt is dried hay and toasted biscuit; yeast suggests phosphorus, sulfur, calcium. In the mouth its light-bodied with succulent-sweet malt against juicy-oily hops, frothy, crisp, clean, oily, invigorated-salivated finish with sticky bitterness. Superb mouth feel and flavor balance, and excellent hop and malt expression, and the phosphoric yeast brings it all together.
Bottle at Bayou in SLC. Hazy straw color with a nice white head. Nice straw, grass, bread aromas. Flavor is dry, rough, rustic, nice. Good crisp feel. A nice pils.
Bottle. Straw beer with a whitish head. light grass and light malt aroma. Light grain and light mineral flavor. Medium bodied. Light grain and light mineral lingers.
A little bitter on the front, but is very drinkable. Taste like a good German beer. Would recommend.

This is spot on for a German pilsner. Those guys at red rock know what they are doing. Clean sweet light bite. Nice bready flavor. Perfect head and mouthfeel. Wow. This is Utah?

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle courtesy of Sledutah, thanks Craig! Clear golden yellow color, thick white head with good retention, solid lacing and champagne bubbles. Aroma of white pepper and bright haystacks. Taste is clean, crisp black pepper and straw, dry finish. Very nice.

Pours clear gold with a thick white head. Fine carbonation rising from the bottom of the glass. Aroma is malt, a little grass and straw. Taste is bready, malty. Nice bitter finish. An excellent pilsener, Red Rock nailed this one. I dont normally drink pilseners because Im addicted to hops but Im glad I tried this one, it takes me back.
500 ml bottle thanks to Craig. Pours a clear copper color with a medium white head. A light fruity lemon nose. The flavor is metallic, lemons, bready, sweet malt. Peppery. Pretty good.

500ml bottle picked up at the Beer Store 
Pours straw yellow with a medium sized white head, good lacing. Aroma is bready, grains and citrus. Taste is bisquity, grainy, grassy with some bitter lemon peel in the finish, dry 
A nice full flavored Pils
Vegetable lager yeast, floral, spicy, and light grainy Pilsner malt aroma and flavor. Substantial bitterness in the flavor.
